description: The US dollar index is testing a key technical level, and it looks like the greenback has peaked or that it is in the process of peaking.
title: Dollar looks like its topping
title_page: Dollar looks like its topping - Business Insider
text:
MPtrader
Now that POTUS has weighed directly into the currency manipulation issue, basically accusing both the EU and China of manipulating their currencies lower to achieve competitive advantage while the US economy attempts to fire on all cylinders amid a rising rate cycle, the trading world has been put on notice that POTUS can and probably will play that game too (or at least jawbone about a lower USD to achieve the same goal without actually forcing the Treasury to intervene in the markets).
It is through this quasi-politically charged prism that we now view the technical set up ahead of the next potentially significant directional move in the USD.
Looking at the BIG picture chart of DXY from its January 2017 high at 103.82, from a pattern perspective, we can make the case that the powerful decline from the January 3, 2017 high at 103.82 to the February 16, 2018 low at 88.25 ended the first major down-leg of an incomplete USD bear phase, followed by a Feb.-July counter-trend rally into the 95.50/65 area, which represents a recovery of almost exactly 50% of the prior initial downleg, and as such, is a natural resistance zone from where we should be expecting a downside pivot reversal that signals the resumption of the dominant underlying bear trend.
Let's notice on the attached Daily Chart of DXY, that during the past 4 weeks, DXY has attempted, but failed to hurdle the 95.50/65 50% resistance zone, and ironically, turned down to 94.50 from the 95.50/65 plateau in reaction to President Donald Trump's comments in his July 19 CNBC interview.
My suspicion is that DXY is peaking, or already has peaked at 95.65, especially when the post-February price action is overlaid on my daily RSI and MACD momentum gauges, which reinforce evidence of upside exhaustion ahead of a downturn.
That said, to trigger an initial sell signal, DXY must break and sustain beneath its multi-month up trendline, now in the vicinity of 94.20.. In the absence of such a close beneath 94.20, let's watch price behavior in and around both the 5 DMA, now at 94.85, and the 20 DMA, now at 94.67. A close beneath the 5 and 20 DMA's will argue strongly for downside continuation that breaks the dominant recovery up trendline at 94.20. Last is 94.56.
